Mike6712
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
1.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 novembre 2022
A fantastic little game about squirrels, with no deal-breakers, provided you don't try to beat the game without playing it.

Honestly, little indie games like this inspire me to write reviews because they're so clever and fun. Nearly everything about this game was awesome, and that "nearly" makes me want to point out the really minor things that could've taken it to a 10/10. I'll keep this spoiler-lite, but just know that this game gets a hearty recommendation from me, and if you plan on playing it, you should stop reading now and give it a shot.

I wish I flipped the pieces over.
Pretty much the only pitfall with this game is that it's a puzzle game that doesn't require you to use the pieces to solve it. It's as if I gave you a jigsaw puzzle of a squirrel, and told you to figure out what animal it is, and after looking at the pieces you determine it to be a squirrel without putting any of them together. In this situation you're right and have done what I've told you, but you've missed the fun. You could still put the pieces together and probably have fun doing so, but if the goal is JUST to find out what the picture is, you'd have to flip them over and assemble them on the blank side if you're really going to engage with the "puzzle" in the way you're meant to. To meet the puzzle's design halfway, you'd have to flip the pieces.

In this game you're tasked with placing cameras during the day to record the nightly activities of squirrels to find out various pieces of information on them. It's an incredibly satisfying core gameplay loop, especially when you go out of your way to engage with that system. However, the game doesn't restrict you from NOT using this mechanic to solve the puzzles.

For example, one of the first tasks they do is ask you to track a squirrel to it's stash and take a picture of it. Now, I had played this first level before on my iPad (before deciding that the port to mobile wasn't the most optimal way to play the game and switched to the PC version). Since I had done this, I already knew where the stash was on my first night, and I just plunked the camera there and basically skipped the whole process. Nothing stopped me from doing this, and it made me wonder... if I just look around a little, couldn't I do this every level moving forward?

Well, you technically can, and that sort of indicates my one problem with this game. The game didn't make me flip the pieces over, and I didn't flip them over myself.

"If given the opportunity, players will optimize the fun out of the game." - Soren Johnson and Sid Meier
See, in later levels you'll be tasked with finding a few different things in that area of the forest, and, remembering my early experience, I gave the area a single walk through looking for interesting places, and I basically "solved" the puzzle the first night. Interestingly enough, the game is prepared for this, and had dialogue that essentially said "No, you're not supposed to do that yet," and then later the character was shocked, SHOCKED, about what I had found, as if I hadn't just submitted the literal same solution but only when the game expected me to.

This left me with mixed feelings, because on one hand I knew I was breaking the rules that the game set out for me by trying to "skip to the end" as it were, but on the other hand the game told me to solve a problem, and I did. I just happened to do it in the least fun way possible.

Armchair developer ideas
I think this could've been changed earlier on, perhaps having locations be abandoned if you disturb them during the day which would cause them to move, resulting in you having to know where your subjects are going before you go there yourself. This would also mean if you mindlessly explore, you'll disturb the squirrels and perhaps get a worse ending, or simply move where they go at night, making your previous research useless. I think this change would've made it far more interesting, having to carefully move through the forest and check your sight-lines carefully to capture (but not disturb!) the squirrels.

Another (possibly far cheaper) solution could instead change the way points-of-interest are highlighted during the day. As they are now, they're typically highlighted in a contrasting color and it makes them incredibly easy to find by just having a wander. Perhaps the colors could've been made to be the same as the environment during the day phase where you're setting up cameras, and only highlight important locations at night. On top of that, perhaps sprinkling more locations that COULD be the final solutions so if you do wander you won't know for sure if the one you're at is the one you need to capture, perhaps even randomizing them between repeated plays.

This only applies to some levels though, as one level circumnavigated this by (light gameplay spoiler) having you capture the path a squirrel takes rather than just it's final destination. If more than just one of the levels did this, I think I wouldn't even have considered my proposed "solutions" I talked about in the previous paragraph. However, given that the final level of the game can (and I mostly did) be solved by just... looking around and trying a few things without engaging with that AMAZING core gameplay mechanic, it makes me feel like something's wrong. I felt like I stumbled into a solution rather than having an "aha!" moment, and that weakened the cool ending for me.

I promise I loved this game.
The stylized graphics, subtle but well composed reactive music, wonderfully written story with charming voice acting, the stellar gameplay... all of it was a fantastic time. Overall for a tiny little indie game it was well worth my support and I am extremely excited for what the devs do next. A couple of hours with this game was extremely refreshing and had me hooked from beginning to end, I just wish I could say it was perfect. If you've read this far and still want to play this game, which you absolutely should, just be sure to flip the pieces over.
 
20/20 Gamer

I didn't experience any glitches, bugs, or issues and the game is smooth and runs well. The art and design is very good and the game is easy on the eyes.

The controls are simple, no issues there. Learning curve very low.

The plot is simple and the puzzle aspect is not complicated. The ending is satisfying. Good music.

Definitely worth the 10$.

369 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 octobre 2022
I don't think NUTS is perfect, but it's certainly beautiful in its own right - and if you're looking for a fun, 3-4 hour adventure/exploration game with a decent enough story, it's hard to go wrong. The clean, minimalist aesthetic is super cool, and each level's palettes feel just right. NUTS' soundtrack brilliantly captures the spirit of the setting, and the camera mechanic is fun - the way each level expands or alters the idea feels very natural, though you can solve most of the puzzles through exploration/brute force; in that regard, there's basically zero replayability once you know the solutions to each level.

That being said, let's address the [squirrel] in the [nest]: the ending. NUTS' ending is beautiful in its own right, but it's very sudden and leaves a lot of lingering questions. I don't think that ambiguity is a bad thing, and I didn't feel unsatisfied by the time I reached the credits; as much as a part of me wishes there had been another chapter or two to slow down the pacing, I think NUTS' strength is knowing just when to end. While the story didn't fall flat for me, I totally understand why someone expecting a tense but generally satisfying climax in the vein of Firewatch - the sort of narrative the trailer plays up - would be disappointed. I don't think you can really go wrong with NUTS, though.
 
AbstrXact_Data

bracia.bee
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 juillet 2022
What is NUTS?

It’s a “squirrel surveillance mystery” but that could mean anything. In NUTS, you are a woodland researcher tasked with following squirrels. You’re placed on a small map and your goal is to track a squirrel that lives in the area until it reaches its destination. It follows the same, pre-recorded route every night and your only means of tracking it is placing cameras and watching footage.

So, the gameplay loop goes like this: Get objective, place camera at starting point, go back to the trailer, watch the footage, see where the squirrel went off camera. Move camera to get vantage on that area. Walk back to the trailer. Repeat until the objective is complete.

While the fact that the squirrels follow the same route every night *becomes* obvious, it is not immediately clear, which left me very confused for the first two objectives. Without any other prompt, I was tasked with finding a squirrel’s food stash. I looked all over for clues, not realizing that what they meant was “keep tracking the first squirrel you took a picture of until it stops.” And then I found the stash by accident without tracking the squirrel at all.

The paths are, of course, designed to keep you guessing. Even paths that look obvious can sometimes give you the run around. Sometimes squirrels will even jump between trees to keep you on your toes. But… they always do the same thing.

Also worth mentioning is that the art style does *so* much work for this game. If this game had “normal” graphics, it would be incredibly frustrating as you peek through grass or try to make out distant shapes. The developers had great foresight in essentially giving you thermal vision at all hours of the day, ensuring that objects of interest are highlighted, and the background is present without bogging you down.

Nuts is a good time, but it’s another one of those games you can only play once. The goal is to follow the squirrels. If you know where they’re going, there’s no game here. So while I recommend NUTs, I also suggest you play it blind or don’t’ play it at all.
 
Slugga

2.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 juillet 2022
It's okay. Safe-for-work version of Squirrel Stapler of Dread XP fame, this is not.
Even at over half off in the summer sale, I did feel like I was shortchanged for what game there is there. I guess I expected a bit more of a mystery that the trailer seems to promise, and that the game would evolve a little from the initial minutes of monitoring squirrels via cameras. But no, pretty much that's your lot. The story is a pretty insubstantial big-corporation-is-bad/nature-profiteering tale that is wafer-thin. I don't know where the steam tages of "time manipulation", "thriller" and "capatalism"(?), came from. But basically, there's maybe 2-2.5 hours, 3 tops, of gameplay here, depending on how long it takes you to get the rough gist of where the squirrels are going each night and then you can quickly work the rest out. It's a pretty unique premise I guess, but wait for a deep discount before picking this one up.

7/10 gameplay, 1/10 ending. I really enjoyed the first half of the game. It was fun to feel like a "real" biologist, but then the second half transforms into a more "action"ey mode that requires you do way too much back and forth. Then you near the end and the game heightens the stakes which was neat, only to completely crap the bend when it came to the actual ending. 1: You have to do stuff you have no reason to think you can do, 2: it in no way follows the story.

Perhaps there are multiple endings and I got the bad one, but I don't think so.
 
40GallonTophat
866 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 avril 2022
Nuts is a walking simulator with light puzzle elements and a well written and emotionally resonant story. Most of the puzzles are tracking the migratory patterns of squirrels through the strategic placement of your cameras. While this could get boring, I found it consistently engaging (unless I put all the cameras in completely the wrong spot and had to start again) and the vibrant contrast in the art style makes them easy to spot. Each level feels unique, both in colour palette, level design, and world-building/story implications. The levels add enough new ideas each time to never feel stale, and learning their layout and using that to compensate for blind spots in your cameras is great fun.

I've finished the game in one day, and it was great from start to finish. The slowly unravelling mystery kept me gripped the whole way through. I absolutely recommend this game!
 
Ash Weston
734 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 avril 2022
I finished this game yesterday. It was on sale and I purchased it for $10.

As other reviewers have stated, there are certain similarities between this and Firewatch. I don't see this as a bad thing necessarily. There were some moments where I felt it was a little TOO similar, but I really loved Firewatch so I was okay with this in general. It has a specific viewpoint and gets that across, and in my opinion can stand on its own.

Right at the beginning, I was excited. I loved the art style and the attention to detail. I enjoyed hearing Nina's voice and felt it was a somewhat interesting system faxing things and having her call me to direct me on what to do next. Her delivery was right on (the voice actress). I love the way she says "squirrel" lol

The sound quality was very good, though I will say some of the music felt out of place. I understand that there is a mysterious theme here, but some moments did not connect with me musically. It would go from whimsical, to ambient, to ominous, and at certain points for me it didn't match. But I quite liked some of the songs in the game. The ambiance you hear in the forest was quite nice too (crickets, frogs, ducks, etc) even if you don't really see these creatures.

Taking/printing pictures was a bit fun. I enjoyed figuring out the puzzles, though a couple of them felt slightly tedious, but overall I had fun figuring out the squirrels' paths. The monitor mechanic was pretty cool, I felt like I was working as a security guard for the squirrels in the forest.

The story is interesting. I am a little mixed on it. On the one hand, I was intrigued in the beginning, my interest was piqued once certain story elements came to you via Nina. However, in my opinion, there was little pay off (both in the end and just as the story progressed). I understand that some of it is possibly up for interpretation or that maybe the laws of this world do not necessarily reflect our real world, but I still think the story lacked a proper payoff.

Overall, I enjoyed myself. I was curious to see the end, and although I don't think it was an EXCELLENT game, I did have fun and it made me feel good playing it. I really enjoyed the world they created and hope that they either expand on it in another game like this, or keep creating games in general even if it is not related to NUTS.

As I stated before, I bought this game for $10 on sale. I personally feel it was worth it. I do not think I would pay more than $15 for it simply because I don't think there is high replayability value. Maybe if there were more hidden secrets and achievements to unlock. But currently I think $10-$15 is a solid asking price.
 
friendlynightmares
0

Évaluation publiée le 6 avril 2022
NUTS is a short and sweet experience that can easily be completed in a few short sessions. If you go into the experience knowing this and are happy to just sit back, relax, and absorb the narrative, you'll probably have a good time, just don't expect too much from it. It's a game about watching squirrels, after all.

If you've played similar games in the past such as Firewatch, you'll probably enjoy this one, but if this is your first foray into these types of games, try to go in with an open mind.

沉浸式角色扮演

游戏采取明暗两色再辅以阴影的美术风格很有特色，利用摄像机记录行踪的解谜也十分新颖
流程不长，却也没少跌宕起伏，奈何结局让人感觉有些遗憾

和教授的电话互动（单方面）让我有种看火人的感觉，但主角始终是个哑巴
是个孤独又不孤独的游戏。

NacalAlpha
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 février 2022
Is it worth full price? Not really. Wait for a sale.
Is it still a solid experience? Absolutely!

You already can tell it has great atmosphere, but what is not as easy to tell is that the gameplay design is really well executed!
Interaction and use of objects and tools work smooth, puzzles are engaging, and each level has a unique challenge to them.

The only major issues are these.
The pacing is rushed in the last quarter, and the content is shallow. You can collect audio logs, but there's VERY few to find.
You can take and send photos of anything, but you'll only get responses out of images related to your main objectives.
And when the story ends, you feel like there were several things that the game was leading up to, but didn't close/answer.

Still, if you like Firewatch's experience, get this on sale!
 
hawkhill

Astralnature
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 février 2022
Plusy:
+ robienie zdjęć wiewiórek
+ małe zwroty akcji
+ ładna grafika
+ urocza dodatkowa historyjka
+ przyjemna rozgrywka, fajny pomysł z tymi kamerami
+ ładna piosenka przy skończeniu gry

Minusy:
- przez całą grę nie spotykamy Simona, który z czasem wydaje się być sussy baka
- w niektórych momentach kolory mapy utrudniają trochę grę (np. zmniejszają widoczność)
- gdy używamy sekretnych kaset, muzyka w tle nie ścisza się automatycznie
- w ostatniej części gry wydaje się, że Ninie bardziej zależało na naszym dzienniku niż na nas, mimo tego, że posiada wszystkie zdjęcia, które jej wysłaliśmy, nagle znika bo "wyjeżdża", nie dzwoni
- zakończenie gry jest urocze, ale kiepskie, nie wiemy co się stało z Simonem, w jakim stanie jest las, a nawet co się mimo wszystko stało z Niną, co z wiewiórkami?

Podsumowując:
Jest to przyjemna gra niewymagająca jakiś specjalnych umiejętności, ale napewno jest ona grą w większości dla osób cierpliwych, ponieważ za niektórymi wiewiórkami można się sporo nabiegać. Główna historia nie powala, niektórymi częściami w fabule jestem zawiedziona.
Jeśli chcesz zagrać w przyjemną gierkę o wiewiórkach, to śmiało, ale jeśli oczekujesz od gry dobrej historii, to lepiej szukaj dalej.
Osobiście gra podobała mi się tylko przez rzeczy wymienione na plus i przez to, że kupując ją nie oczekiwałam, że będzie tu jakaś historia. Chciałam po prostu wyluzować robiąc zdjęcia wiewiórkom.
 
KanapeczkaZumi

В основе игры необычная механика: нужно расставлять камеры и записывать перемещения белок. Камер всего две-три, поэтому за один раз не получится проследить, откуда и куда они бегают. Приходится двигать камеры и надеяться, что в этот раз направляешь объектив в нужном направлении.

Игра не очень длинная. Как раз чтобы наиграться с камерами и не успеть заскучать.

49 produits enregistrés

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
6.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 janvier 2022
This is very cute and the stylised artwork is quite striking. It was a lot of fun and while it can get a bit repetitive, as others have noted, I really enjoyed the time spent on this one. It's quite relaxing at first — it has notes of Firewatch — and makes me long to be a researcher beavering away in a quiet, secluded forest, surrounded by nature and miles away from humans/civilisation.

There's a few little twists and the later chapters can be quite tense as the game gives the impression that shifty things are afoot. They are, just not quite what you think. The music is especially good in the second half of the game.

The ending was not what I was expecting at all, but I actually liked it - oh to sail away on a boat full of squirrels. Completely nuts!

This is an amazing game! Really well-designed and thought out, witha a unique visual style. The gameplay seems simple: position cameras, record video, and use it to track squirrels for a researcher. But there are a lot of details to discover along the way, and a mysterious plot that slowly gets uncovered as you progress. Absolutely great way to spend a few hours.

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 décembre 2021
Fun game with an interesting style. Love the mystery aspect, but I felt it ended a bit abruptly. Short game that could be done in one longer sitting or just a couple of 1-2 hour sittings.

Unfortunately, the game had some technical issues for me. The windowed mode toggle did not work for me. Between every chapter where there was a black loading screen, the game would hang for a second and crash. On the loading screen for chapter 6, the game kept crashing. It took me a number of tries to get through. By the time I ended the game, I couldn't see the ending credits. It rolled to black as the song played.

This is an inexpensive game though, and I got it on sale, so it was easily worth it for me. Give it a try and hopefully you won't have the technical issues that I have.

The story is all over the place and full of loose ends, but the squirrel tracking game gets you pretty immersed into the game.

SauciBeans
231 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
3.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 novembre 2021
I really enjoyed the first hour or so, as I was easing myself into the game. Unfortunately, I can't recommend the game as a whole.

I actually enjoyed it mechanically. Tracking squirrels by studying multiple cameras at once was a fun bit of detective work, even if there wasn't much variation in the "puzzles" themselves. The plot and the writing, however... I just couldn't connect to the characters (well, character) at all, and the writing took me out of the experience once the plot started picking up.

As for the abruptness of the ending and the fact that so much isn't explained, I'm not too disappointed. I understand the decision to leave some things unexplained, but there were many guns that had been set up, and very, very few of them were actually fired.
 
Jacic

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 novembre 2021
I recommend NUTS but not that is not a strong recommendation. As a very simplistic game (from a gameplay standpoint), I measure it to the likes of Firewatch, What Remains of Edith Finch and The Stanley Parable. Sadly it is nowhere near as memorable but still worth the short ride.

The gameplay is to observe and photograph squirrels and fax those photos over to your contact who you only communicate with through a phone. So kind of similar to Firawatch in that sense - you have another person who you never see but is your only human contact. But NUTS actually has very well defined levels while Firewatch kind of keeps that illusion better. In NUTS, you can walk from one side of the level to the other in around 1-1.5 minutes. So they are really small and you only have a few. 7 maybe? The 2.6 hours I have in it is not doing thing optimally - I explored a lot and missed a few clues here and there so if you are smarter or have better luck, the game is around 1.5 hours long. But it looks nice.

It feels like the thesis work of someone that got some extra attention to round it out for a commercial release.
 
Zazamoukh

499 produits enregistrés

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 aout 2021
Style and gameplay-wise a mixture between Firewatch and Return of the Obra Dinn, with charming and colorful lo-res polygon graphics as well as a creative investigative gameplay based on placing cameras and going through your found footage.

The atmosphere is great and the nifty puzzle mechanic lifts this above your average indie title. However: the writing is a bit so-so, and does lean a lot on the vibes of aforementioned Firewatch. That the ending is quite anti-climactic doesn't help things either.

That being said, Nuts is an overall enjoyable experience despite its flaws, and I'm very interested in seeing what this little team will do next.

Keroppi
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 juillet 2021
Short but sweet


First thing you will see, is well the visuals obviously! They very are striking. There is sharp contrast of background to environment to interactable elements. Another part of the visuals is the very neat restricted color cell shaded thing going on.

Next off is the gameplay, at its base It is plenty intuitive and enjoyable. Positioning the cameras, where you think the squirrels will go next, watching your recordings that night and then adjusting them again in the morning, Doing that again and again until you have found your goal. It ends up feeling like a puzzle in a way, trying to figure out from their previous paths and the local terrain where they are coming from or going and finally getting that perfect shot to fax off to your coworker and start on your next assignment. I would say I really enjoyed the gameplay, there really wasn't a moment where I felt bored or unengaged.

Now let's talk about the story, without any spoilers I can say its good and that I got extremely invested. As you progress through your assignments you go from a remote researcher occasionally talking to a stranger for progress reports, to feeling like you are actually friends with Nina, (your coworker) and slowly uncovering why you're there and why that research is so important.

Finally to the sound track, whether it be the ambient sounds, the voice acting, or the music, it all adds together making a very cohesive environment. The sounds of nature as you walk though the forest, the light music that makes things almost feel whimsical as you do your job, or alternatively how serious of a situation you are in. Heck the credits music left me feeling like I might cry after all I had been though.



I played this game to completion in one session because I genuinely couldn't put it down. I was having quite a bit of fun and had become extremely invested in the story.

Overall I seriously recommend this game, it might be short, but the experience was worth every penny.

 
Tallbird Cowboy

Recommandé
4.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 juillet 2021
I have seen quite a few of negative reviews for this game so let me give the top positive comments I have.

-This game does an excellent job of immersing you in the mystery. Very few mystery/detective games do you have to put in the work to actual figure out what is going on. With the camera and tracking system this game choose to deliver this sleuthing experience gave a very realistic and genuine feel.

- I really like the art design of the game. Especially the color scheme. It added to mystery/detective vibe.

- The use of squirrels as a vehicle to drive your story was genius. It really lead to a good story flow and at no point within the game play was I left scratching my head.
 
demar182
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 juillet 2021
Nuts is a first person exploration game that sees you setting up cameras to try and film squirrel activity in Melmoth Forest. Your guide, Nina, is just a phone call away to help you to capture the footage she needs...but is there a deeper reason that she cares so much for this forest..? And aren't those squirrels acting a bit...odd?

This game features:

- Unique cel-shaded / limited palette aesthetic
- Relaxed gameplay free of combat, time limits etc
- Using surveillance equipment to track and photograph
- Chapter select on completion.
- Squirrels! Lots and lots of squirrels!

This game reminded me of Firewatch, thanks to the relaxed gamepley, phone contact with Nina, the setting, and the gradual unfolding of the story.

There is just 1 difficulty level, so my experience is based on this.

This game took me around 4.5 hours to complete and 100%.

The Good:

- Gorgeous aesthetic, though the sharp contrast may be a bit marmite (like it or love it).

- Interesting (though short) and unexpected story, with a good script and voice acting.

- It feels rewarding when you achieve your objectives (usually involving capturing a photo of a squirrel in a particular place).

- Lovely minimalist soundtrack.

The Bad:

- Repetitive gameplay. You will make lots and lots of incremental adjustments to your cameras to try and track those squirrels, and each time you have to run back to your caravan to record the footage. If you haven't put your cameras in the best place, it feels like a wasted run. Thankfully the maps aren't big enough to make this a big problem, but this was the biggest downside for me.

- Only a few areas to explore.

- Not much variety in equipment etc.

The Rest:

I've seen a few reviews that talk about being disappointed with the ending because they felt that it didn't answer any of the questions raised during the rest of the game. Without spoiling anything, I personally really enjoyed the ending, and felt it really suited the game.

All in all, I enjoyed my time with Nuts. Though brief, the game doesn't outstay its welcome (which I suspect would have been the case if it were any longer), and tells an interesting and unique story in an engaging way. There really aren't any other games like this out there, so if you enjoy playing things that are a bit different, this is well worth a look.
 
johelian

Pazzers
1
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 juin 2021
Produit reçu gratuitement

IXQUILO

Nuts é uma tentativa de criar um jogo thriller de narrativa mais adulta assim como fez Firewatch, mas o que ele alcança é um patamar simples, porém de identidade própria e levemente intrigante. Admito que, se esse jogo tivesse saído antes de Firewatch ele teria mais relevância pra mim, apesar da história ser completamente diferente do já citado jogo.

O game é simples, sem muitas mecânicas e com alguns problemas sérios de seleção de cor e otimização. Em suas incríveis 3 horas de jogo você irá passear por cenários com pequenos fragmentos de história e mecânicas simples de vigilância. Seu objetivo? Tirar fotos de esquilos, exatamente, esquilos. Você é um contratado para estudar a vida local em forma de fotografia. O que é curioso nesse jogo é que sua narrativa esconde uma outra história, que parece cheia de reviravoltas mas deixa infinitas pontas soltas e o que poderia ser um grande plot twitch, é, nada mais nada menos do que só uma narrativa sem sal e sem mistério de verdade, visto que tudo é entregue nas primeiras horas de jogo e daí ele acaba.

É BONITO, MAS VALE A PENA?

Então, se você gosta de jogos de investigação rasos, simples e que vão direto ao ponto, com uma pitada pra relaxar e uma ambientação de visual beeeem diferente, ele é um jogo legal, vale a experiência e definitivamente é um jogo divertido. Mas eu não o recomendaria, porque ele nada mais é do que uma versão de Firewatch mais simples, e, honestamente, achei mais intrigante o outro citado. No entanto, visualmente o jogo chama a atenção, e o dinamismo da história, pra quem gosta de algo mais direto, é um atrativo que de fato faz valer a pena a experiência.

No mais, é isso.
 
Mirage42cit
969 produits enregistrés
0

Jorgazoo
1,901 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 31 mai 2021
I played this game for the first time at EGX Rezzed in London, followed immediately and bought on release date. I loved and still love everything about it.

It has a very the relaxing and increasingly foreboding atmosphere of and feel of Firewatch for it's soul, but it's heart is the TRULY original camera game mechanic: Squirrel starts at point A and travels to point B along the same route every night. Aware of point A, you place 3 remote video cameras in the day, hit record and review the footage the next day and reposition the cameras till you home in on point B.

It's a simple concept executed so with so much freedom in camera angle and location that it's hard to get bored of. I cannot recommend this game enough. <3

There's so little I can say about this game without spoiling it. I loved the gameplay, first off: having to track these squirrels by placing cameras and reviewing footage was unique and compelling. The game's story is gorgeous, and a little sad. I'll be thinking of this game for a long time.

3.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 mai 2021
Produit reçu gratuitement

NUTS was a lot of fun. It was whacky, weird, eccentric, and very much its own thing. I'm not entirely sure what I expected when going into the game, beyond a cool looking little walking sim with some puzzles thrown it, but honestly, it was a bit more than that. Much to my surprise, pleasantly. There were points around the middle of the game where the core mechanics felt as though they were getting a little tedious, but luckily that's right around the point where things switched up a bit and it sucked me right back in. The overall story is weird as all hell, and I'm still not 100% sure what was happening at all points, especially the end, but that's something that works in the game's favour in my opinion. All in all, very memorable and well worth it I'd say.

Évaluation publiée le 7 mai 2021
NUTS is a great proof of concept and I really look forward to the devs next game.
I enjoyed my time with the game it's very charming and unique but the story is a huge letdown and feels like several half formed ideas put together that never really click. I get the feeling they the devs wanted to play with your expectations but the game isn't long enough for that to really work. Instead the ending seems to come out of nowhere and none of the major plot threads are resolved. Again I actually really loved the game and do recommend playing it but don't get to invested. The only reason I'm coming across so negative is that I feel NUTS had potential to be so much more but it just isn't

tasteful sidebirb
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 mai 2021
Produit reçu gratuitement

You are probably here to read something like "Play this, is good" or "Don't play, no good". But let me tell you: It is never that simple. So, I will explain why I recommend playing this game. And don't you come in the end I didn't warn you, 'cause I will. But more on that later,

First, NUTS is a squirrel-filming-simulator. More precise: the story unfolds as you enter Melmoth Forest to do some surveillance of the local squirrel population. You are not the first scientist to do so, but there is need to do it again. So you enter your trailer and start your first day. You will get instructions over phone so you always got a goal to fulfill. This evolves from simple to more complicated. Depending on the tasks you will need several days to submit your results via fax. Yes, fax. It's all very oldschool, but at least there are videocameras that work just fine. Via some monitors you can look at the night's results and screenshot the important parts. And then you leave again, re-assembling the cameras and following the tracks.

That's what you do. But there is of course some more things I would like to tell. The art style is amazing, the simple adumbrated forest shines in bright violet, clear blue or vibrant shades of green. You never walk in silence, there is always rustling of leaves and cracking branches around. No horror game sounds, but a very authentic scenery that creates the feeling of wandering the woods for real. And the squirrels just look and act like real squirrels, except maybe some strange behaviour you will find out about.

But let me put that clear: NUTS is a game with a message. Behind all that squirrel following thing a serious topic is hiding. I will not go into detail, but the more you find out, the deeper you dig into that ♥♥♥♥. And the end straight-out shocked me.

So, conclusion: NUTS is a great game. Of course, there is limited content, four or five levels and a play time of five to six hours is not indicating an open world sandbox adventure. But I had to think about NUTS a lot, and it can be challenging at times. But be prepared: sometimes patience and luck is what you need more than strategy and cleverness. The controls are smooth, no problem at this point. I hope that helped you out a bit and that you will enjoy NUTS. If you want to read more about exceptional indie games, follow my curator group IGR Daily

Évaluation publiée le 2 mai 2021
Nuts ma niesamowity klimat, stwarzany przez ciekawą mechanikę, wyraziste elementy stylistyczne, nastrojową warstwę muzyczną, a wreszcie przez fabułę – intrygującą, angażującą i szczególnie ważną, bo ekokrytyczną. Na dodatek gra momentami zahacza o konwencje thrillera. Całość więc zdecydowanie na plus.

Jedynymi zastrzeżeniami jest stosunkowo krótka rozgrywka i niewielka liczba znajdziek – po ukończeniu Nuts pozostaje chęć na zgłębienie tajemnic tego mikrokosmosu. Mapa sprzyja rozbudowanym sekretom i zagadkowym miejscom, stąd liczę na dalszy rozwój w tym kierunku.

hobgoblinette
1,351 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 avril 2021
This is one of those games where you pretty much immediately know whether you'd like this or not. So if you think this is up your alley, then go ahead, I promise it's satisfying and plays well. You won't be disappointed.

The gameplay loop for the most part is simple. You set up cameras, you wait until nightfall, and you review footage. Then, the next day, you set up cameras based on what your findings from last night were. Rinse and repeat. It's pretty fun and engaging, really. If that sounds boring to you - trust me, it's not. It really makes you feel like a detective, of a sort. A squirrel detective?

And then of course there are twists and turns in the story. They really keep things interesting. If you think this game only pretends to be about squirrels... hah, I could tell you whether that's true or not, but that would be a slight spoiler, wouldn't it? Nah. I won't. The game manages to go in the face of your expectations quite expertly. I'll leave it to blow your mind.

And of course there's the visuals. They really make you feel immersed in the world. That's what they're for, right? They also look rather pretty. But for the most part, they're transparent; what you see is the forest around you. You're really there. The great soundscape also helps achieve this effect.

If you're worried if this is a horror game - I'd say answering this is a spoiler in itself, so I'll just say that it is not.

I finished in one day. I'd recommend it to anyone who likes nature, a good story, and appreciates cute animals.
 
Vitlök

Évaluation publiée le 24 avril 2021
If you enjoy somewhat vague story driven walking simulators... this is your game. It has a really great atmosphere, the music is beautiful, the art direction feels unique. The pacing is pretty decent. It's a slower game being a walking simulator, but the objectives are always clear. So the pacing is pretty tight for a walking simulator. The interactivity with the environment is pretty fun too with chunky buttons, fax machines, a working GPS, etc.

This game isn't everyone's cup of tea. But I sure enjoyed it. :)

Recommandé
4.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 avril 2021
From such simplistic routine, you might think this puzzling game filled with squirrels would be quite laidback. After a few hours rearranging cameras, crossreferencing time of the squirrels' midnight run. I really enjoyed the scenery of Melmoth Forest, I even spent time in the beginning wandering around.

This game reminded me of one of my favorite games I've seen called "The Return of the Obra Dinn" since of it's two colored art; I felt different emotions from this from a peaceful forest to a dreaded swampland filled with metal and wood. Even from one of the chapters of my photos being; unsquirreled and published to some newspaper. I got worried, even for Nina and Simon... Especially Simon.

Well, thank you for the game. I'll treasure it like the squirrels with their nuts.

(Haha, I even noticed just now I published my review in discussion which was, accidental.)

rando
341 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
4.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 mars 2021
Definitely a good one! I really got into using all of the equipment, staring into the monitors and zooming/enhancing BladeRunner-style, whispering about squirrels as I print a photo off and pin it the cork board for tomorrow.
I usually don't care for audio design and music in games, but NUTS really nails it, and I couldn't ignore how perfect all the sound effects were. Without spoiling anything about the plot, the music really makes some masterful atmospheres, sometimes relaxing and sometimes foreboding.
As a forestry student who has done some solo-research for the department, I think I have a psychological dependency on pleasing the faculty and not messing up the data, so 'figuring stuff out' and having the project come together felt great, especially as it all builds onto the plot.
I admit I finished it wanting a little more--it is a short game, a few hours. And I really would like to see the gameplay expanded upon in another game, incorporating more than just photos into your reports. I wish there were more types of equipment to use and that the 'unraveling' of things went on longer. Granted, the last couple chapters manage to use the same mechanics in some very interesting ways that I definitely appreciate.
I should add, I was playing on Linux and the whole thing ran perfectly despite there not being explicit native support--thanks Proton.

2.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 mars 2021
A short, yet wonderful little game.
You spend your time watching what the squirrels are up to at night in a little puzzle where you have to set up cameras to find out where the squirrels go and what they do.
This relaxing gameplay goes alongside a little story that, for its length, is full of mysteries, some of which leave room for interpretation, but without hurting the story overall.

All in all, if you like short and relaxing games that you can just play in one sitting this is the game for you.

xx2cd91xx2
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 février 2021
This one is more a neutral review than positive, I can see many people liking NUTS and just as many swinging the opposite way but I would expect the the majority of people to fall into the middle with a resounding shrug, in other words its OK.

The immediately interesting thing (to me anyway) is the promise of mystery, you'll be a researcher out in the backwoods tracking the movements of the local squirrels but theres stuff afoot, both from a shady property developer looking to pave over the forest and also from the squirrels themselves. its starts with a slow burn and builds ultimately to a fairly mundane peak.

The ultimate problem isn't however with the story itself but in how its delivered. You'll explore the forest in the day and place cameras, then later review the footage to find out if theres anything interesting going on, moving cameras the next day to follow up on anything you caught a glimpse of the night before. So far so good and you may be wondering whats wrong and its just that theres nothing going on apart from the one story event in each area. and thats what causes me to go meh at the end of the game. It doesn't feel as though I'm making discoveries ,the main storyu beats are handed out and explained and it feels like I have a very passive role in the story, if there had been other events off the beaten path to find and expand the story on your own then I think the game would feel better even if the story itself for the most part remains the same.

Overall NUTS is fine, I don't regret playing it, and it could be expanded into something really great with a bunch more work, if you're after a short novel experience then you could go far worse than NUTS.
 
LocalFire

Recommandé
8.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 février 2021
Really enjoyed game, they did a great job of creating an atmosphere that captures the beauty and eeriness of very old forests. That tasks seem simple (follow the path of the squirrels) but do require some thinking. The squirrels' odd behaviour together with the worrisome observations by your boss/scientist Nina about this impact study you are working on keeps you guessing at what it is really going on. I liked the resolution as well, though they leave you guessing on the details (SPOILER I think the unseen Simon was possibly sabotaging the study).
 
Fallover
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 février 2021
Very interesting and unique central mechanic, very well executed. I'm a hobbyist amateur photographer IRL so the entire setup was kinda perfect for me, I spent about as much time trying to frame the perfect shot with the camera controls as I did actually doing research! This was clearly a labour of love and I'd love to see what the developers do next.

The elephant in the room is the length, as other reviewers have said. Clocked in at about 3 and a half hours from start to finish (4 if you count the time spent on the demo, which crosses over with the first level of the full game), with about half an hour of that being recovering from Unity crashes in the last couple of levels. So by many standards it's very short, especially with a 15€ price point. I would have loved to see it expanded on in a bit more depth (the story as it is definitely leaves room for that)

Overall I'd definitely recommend it as one of those unique kinds of experience that could only be told as a game, but given the runtime you might want to keep your eye out for a sale.
 
Jethrain
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 février 2021
Short and sweet, and absolutely fantastic for it.

Stylistically inspired, NUTS is a duochromatic jaunt through atmospheric forests that have you looking back over your shoulder in case someone's stalking just a few steps behind, hidden in the fog. However, the spooky vibe is offset with a focus on the theme of protecting nature - something near and dear to my heart. I became hugely invested in what started as a quirky premise - tracking squirrels - and by the end of the game around 4 hours in, I definitely had an emotional connection to the experience.

This is a perfect game, too, for the lockdown blues, and reminded me what it's like to be outside without a care.

Good games aren't always long games, or the most realistic games, or the most complicated games. While those are all admirable accolades, I love NUTS for being an original game. It really feels like it did something different that I hadn't seen before, and not just for the sake of it; something which is rare to achieve, I feel!

Thank you for making this game - I loved it! <3
 
emmakpark
492 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 février 2021
Я получил от этой игры не совсем то, что ожидал. Я думал, что это будет что-то типа игры песочницы, где вы медитативно приближаетесь к разгадке большой тайны, но оказалось, что это линейная сюжетная игра. В какой-то момент мне начало казаться, что это хоррор, и игра просто пытается расслабить меня повторяющимися действиями, чтобы потом напугать, привнеся неожиданные сюрпризы, но оказалось что нет. Я всё время ждал, что эта игра вот вот раскроется, но этого так и не случилось, хотя можно было придумать очень много разных крутых геймплейных идей на этой основе. В итоге геймплей оказался, на мой взгляд, довольно однообразным и предсказуемым, история не раскрытой, а куча возможных механик не реализована.
Но почему же лично я остался полностью доволен покупкой этой игры? Есть две вещи которые полностью преображают восприятие этой игры: это МУЗЫКА и ЭСТЕТИКА. Эта игра не просто так получила награду за звуковое оформление на IndieCade, она полностью заслуживает этого! Музыка и звуки здесь очень умело манипулируют чувствами, погружая игрока в игру. А минималистичный стиль только усиливает этот эффект. Как раз из-за звукового оформления игра местами начинает казаться хоррором. Звуки в игре сделаны действительно хорошо, а визуальное оформление выглядит очень интересно.
В итоге я бы сказал, что в этой игре не стоит ждать чего-то особенного от геймплея или истории, эту игру стоит оценивать как картину, как что-то, что должно вызывать эмоции, погружать в себя. И возможно то, как игра это делает, вдоновит вас на что-то.
Да, я бы сказал, что в итоге эта игра "вдохновляющая", по крайней мере для меня.
 
markilic

It took me 2.4h to finish and it doesn't have replay value, so be advised if you don't like short games or the price tag.
 
Steenus Weanus
531 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 février 2021
Produit reçu gratuitement

NUTS is a short and unique experience that lived up to my expectations. The game loop of placing cameras by day and tracking squirrel movement by night is satisfying in and of itself, but it is the atmosphere of the environments that take the experience to the next level. While the levels are gorgeous shades of lines and colour, the detailed soundscape makes you believe you’re hiking through a real forest. After a few assignments you’ll no longer be looking at the terrain as a human, but will have completely embraced a squirrel state of mind. What would I do if I were a squirrel?

The story that drives the experience isn’t always evenly paced, but it spins an intriguing tale that manages to play with both your expectations and genre tropes. The overall feeling is a bit eery, almost Lynchian in how things seem to be normal but maybe aren't quite as normal. The game doesn't outstay its welcome and even should you lose interest in the squirrel voyeurism before it's over, there's always the environments and the story to drag you across the finish line.
 
Christophe

Evokes Firewatch strongly, but is quite short. I got it at 16.99 and I feel an appropriate price would be maybe 10-14.
 
snowe
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 février 2021
a short game that proves solid pacing trumps overtly long play times. it's got a gorgeous but devilishly simple art style that it changes per chapter to prevent from the visuals being too monotonous, some really well done sound design, especially the sole voice actress in the English version. All built around a simple but engaging core gameplay loop of camera placement puzzles to find where the squirrel runs off to their stashes.

my only real complaints for this are that the story piqued my interest but goes nowhere so i'd have maybe enjoyed a little more of it and i did get a visual hiccup in the third chapter but it wasn't game impacting.

end verdict: Squirrels can be fun and engaging even if they're little s**** to catch on camera. a really good game for a relaxing afternoon.

Recommandé
5.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 7 février 2021
NUTS very much feels like the entry into a much larger world where squirrels run rampant with plans of their own. The experience is no shorter than a number of well-loved horror indie titles, and it runs with the same goal. Get the player in, let them experience the creation, get the player out.

It's streamlined and so well crafted. Every chapter has a multitude of secrets and the expectation is that you will explore. So explore. Have fun. Make connections. Then buckle up for what the NUTS team brings next!

Beautiful experience! The aesthetic is perfect for the atmosphere as well as the main set of challenge mechanics! The dialogue and the voice acting as well as the sound in general, were spot on -- reinforcing the immersion and creating a compelling world. The squirrels steal the show though: look, movement, and personality! I enjoyed every minute of it and strongly recommend for anyone who likes unique visuals, interesting tales, and a twist on visual/spatial puzzles.

Recommandé
6.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 février 2021
Produit reçu gratuitement

If the Easter bunny was a squirrel with a superb visual presentation and audio to go with it.

I had a lot of fun hunting for nuts and just generally wandering around in beautiful environments.
None of the puzzles are super hard nor boringly simple and I was constantly pushed along by the story.
Every level switched it up slightly to keep the mechanics fresh throughout.

Now if only I knew what all the apple cores were about ...

Received the game for free during beta testing when the first part of the level was released.
Almost everything was changed or worked out further since then and all for the better.

Ace
105 produits enregistrés
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 février 2021
Good first person walking sim/detective game in the vein of Firewatch, though with more engaging gameplay. I will say that the novelty of the gameplay loop kinda wears off after the first chapter, and that I wish there were a bit more variety. You do spend the whole game placing cameras around and following squirrels through the footage. That said, it's only like 2-3 hours long, so it didn't get tiresome for me or anything. The story is good, though I do kinda wish it had a voiced protagonist. You're very much a non-character in this, and you have no name or backstory. I get that that might've put it too close to Firewatch, but it just felt off to me, being called by the game's actual main character over the phone and listening as she has one-sided conversations. Might've felt different if I'd ever gotten to hear more than just one character's voice, even if it weren't the player character. The story itself was good and kept me engaged, but it wasn't stellar or anything. The visuals, of course, are great. And not just aesthetically. If the game had been in a more generic, multi-colored art style, I can only imagine how much of a nightmare it would have been to track these squirrels as they scurry about, running through bushes and climbing up trees. The stylized color palettes make sure that the squirrels stand out from their environments as much as possible. On that note, the design overall is great. The way you interact with things in the world (mainly the camper in which you conduct your research) feels so natural. There's hardly any UI, just things which diegetically exist in the world that you use in intuitive ways, mostly only using LMB. Makes me wish more games were like that. I only wish the game weren't so repetitive, because I feel that it barely taps into the potential of its mechanics. That said, I enjoyed this very much and would recommend it to anybody who's into this sort of game.
 
Need_New_Job_plz
0
Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
2.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 février 2021
I played the demo for this and loved the art style, the aesthetic of it all is really nice and relaxing. There's good ambient music that unlike a lot of games isn't super loud and really adds to the mood of the game. There were a lot of unexpected turns throughout the story and it was very worthwhile. I don't think it is massively replayable because the world is pretty static and you'll know where everything is the next time around, but I think I will be messing around with it again to find easter eggs and get the last two achievements.

Overall a great game that I am glad I bought.
 
Shamwowser

Personne n'a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
6.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 février 2021
I thought this game would be right up my alley. I'm all for slow-paced narrative mystery games with science-y stuff, and I expected this one to be similar to Beyond Blue (apart from the visuals). I didn't vibe with it at all, though. After finishing it, I understood that I'm not in its actual target group, which might explain some but not all of it. I can see why the game appeals to a lot of more "regular" gamers, but I can't recommend it for those more like myself and I thought it had a lot of issues anyway.

TL;DR: unique game with cool gameplay concept but tedious execution, NO SAVE during chapters, overall a bit bare-bones; descends from "field research sim" into drama/tension and nonsense.

Where to start? The tediousness.
It took me a while to figure out the camera placing and much longer to discover settings for the tv set that weren't introduced. And maybe I spent too much time analysing footage and put too much thought into placing the cameras, but my progress felt rather glacial. When I got bored and tired, I couldn't even save my progress to take a break. I also got my character stuck once and had to restart the game - and lose my progress again. No manual save and no save at all during a chapter, are you kidding me?!

I think another tedious thing for me were the minimal graphics - in the beginning, I could barely see where I was supposed to go. I played the demo and thought it was ok, but I guess my eyes started feeling more strained after a while. Might be just me though, haven't heard that complaint from anyone else.

It sure didn't help that I couldn't get my FPS over 20-25, even though my graphics and memory are well within the system requirements and the visuals didn't look very demanding. Maybe it's because I use Linux with Proton, but I've never had this issue before.

There was nothing that I particularly liked looking at, either. Nothing to do apart from the camera stuff and phone conversations - why can you even pick up kitchen equipment and toilet paper if the only thing you can do with it is dropping it again?

This brings us to my next problem, the narrative and pacing feeling a bit weird and confusing. I was seriously wondering if it was a bug or if there was supposed to be a time loop when suddenly everything was reset and I was prompted to send a check-in fax again, because there was no mention of being transported to different locations.
I got a lot of continuity errors, I think mostly from doing things differently than the game expected me to do them (e.g. Nina referring to things I hadn't done, or talking about upcoming tasks that I'd done already).
...I deleted something here because now I'm not sure how much of it might have been intentional, but it sure didn't work for me. I didn't manage to suspend disbelief and get immersed in the story.

Overall, the game didn't meet the admittedly high expectations I had after the demo. It's not the kind of game I thought it would be, and I get that that's not really the game's fault, but there were also a lot of small things that honestly made it feel unfinished to me.

* * *

If you're here for wildlife observations and research, check out Beyond Blue. If you like chill and story-driven games in general, check out my curator Peaceful Adventures and Stories. You're also welcome to join the group.
 
löyly
